content: The Act is titled the "Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal Land Conveyance Act of 2006". It pertains to the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal. The Blunt Reservoir feature is part of the Oahe Unit, James Division, authorized by the Act of August 3, 1968. The Commission refers to the Commission of Schools and Public Lands of the State. A nonpreferential lease parcel is a land parcel purchased by the Secretary for use with the Blunt Reservoir feature or the Pierre Canal feature. The term "nonpreferential lease parcel" refers to land purchased by the Secretary for use with the Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal features, as designated by the Secretary in 2001. The "Pierre Canal feature" is part of the Oahe Unit, James Division, authorized under the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin program. The "Pierre Canal feature" is part of the Oahe Unit, James Division, authorized under the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin program. A "preferential leaseholder" is a person or descendant holding a lease on a preferential lease parcel as of January 1, 2001. A "preferential lease parcel" is land purchased by the Secretary for specific use. The term "preferential lease parcel" refers to land purchased by the Secretary for use in connection with the Blunt Reservoir feature or the Pierre Canal feature, and identified as such on the Bureau of Reclamation's 2001 lease roster. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Commissioner of Reclamation. The term "unleased parcel" refers to land purchased by the Secretary for use in connection with the Blunt Reservoir feature or the Pierre Canal feature, which is not currently under lease. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Commissioner of Reclamation. The Blunt Reservoir feature and Pierre Canal feature land purchased by the Secretary for use are deauthorized. The State may accept the portions of these features in "as is" condition. The State may agree to accept the Blunt Reservoir feature and Pierre Canal feature in "as is" condition, along with any liability and responsibility associated with ownership, operation, or maintenance of these features. The State may accept the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal features with associated obligations, including expired easements and purchase options for leaseholders. Outstanding obligations will be binding on the State. Oil, gas, mineral, and other rights will transfer to the State through conveyance or sale. The State will accept the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal features with associated obligations, including expired easements and purchase options for leaseholders. Oil, gas, mineral, and other rights will transfer to the State through conveyance or sale, subject to existing third-party reservations and permits. The State will accept the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal features with associated obligations, including expired easements and purchase options for leaseholders. Conveyance to the State will include oil, gas, mineral, and other rights subject to existing third-party reservations and permits. Additionally, conveyance will be subject to reservations by the United States and conditions specified in the Act of May 19, 1948 for wildlife conservation purposes. The preferential leaseholder has an option to purchase the preferential lease parcel from the Secretary or the Commission. The terms of the purchase include various options for the preferential leaseholder. The preferential leaseholder has the option to purchase the lease parcel from the Secretary or the Commission on various terms, including a cash purchase option. The preferential leaseholder can purchase the lease parcel from the Secretary or the Commission, with the value of the parcel determined under paragraph (4) minus ten percent of that value. The preferential leaseholder can purchase the lease parcel with 10 percent down and the rest paid over 30 years at 3 percent interest. If the parcel is under $10,000, it must be purchased on a cash basis. The option to purchase must be exercised within 5 years of the enactment of the Act. The preferential leaseholder has 5 years from the enactment of the Act to exercise the option to purchase the lease parcel. Until then, they can continue leasing the parcel under the same terms. The value of the preferential lease parcel will be determined. The preferential leaseholder has 5 years to purchase the lease parcel under the same terms. The value of the preferential lease parcel will be determined by its fair market value for agricultural purposes, less 25 percent. The Act allows preferential leaseholders to purchase land at fair market value. Disputes over property value will be resolved according to federal regulations. If a leaseholder fails to buy within 5 years, the land may be offered to the State of South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks. If a preferential leaseholder does not purchase a parcel within the specified period, the land may be offered to the South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks for wildlife habitat mitigation. Proceeds from land sales will be deposited as miscellaneous funds in the Treasury. Proceeds from land sales under the Pick-Sloan project will be deposited as miscellaneous funds in the Treasury and made available to the State for establishing a trust fund to pay county taxes on lands received by the State Department of Game, Fish, and Parks. Nonpreferential lease parcels and unleased parcels will be conveyed by the secretary to the state within a year. The Secretary will offer to convey nonpreferential lease parcels and unleased parcels of the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal to the South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks for wildlife habitat mitigation within a year of the enactment of the Act. The South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks will use land conveyed for wildlife habitat mitigation lost due to the Pick-Sloan project. The South Dakota Commission of Schools and Public Lands may allow land exchanges for nonpreferential lease parcels and unleased parcels with their concurrence. The South Dakota Commission of Schools and Public Lands, with the concurrence of the Department of Game, Fish, and Parks, may permit land exchanges at Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal. Priority for exchanging nonpreferential lease parcels is given to current lessees and adjoining landowners. Priority for exchanging parcels or unleased parcels at Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal is as follows: (i) Exchanges with current lessees for nonpreferential lease parcels, (ii) Exchanges with adjoining and adjacent landowners for unleased parcels and nonpreferential lease parcels not exchanged by current lessees. A perpetual easement for water conveyance structure is reserved by the United States as a condition of the land exchange. The United States reserves a perpetual easement for water conveyance structures over the Pierre Canal feature. The United States will not be liable for damages related to any act or occurrence after the conveyance of a parcel under this Act. Effective on the date of conveyance under this Act, the United States will not be liable for damages arising from any act, omission, or occurrence related to the parcel, except for negligence committed before the conveyance. This section does not add to any liability under the Federal Tort Claims Act. During the interim period before conveyance, the Secretary will lease parcels under existing terms. No additional liability is added under the Federal Tort Claims Act. The Secretary will continue to lease preferential and nonpreferential parcels under existing terms until conveyance. Within 180 days, the Secretary will provide the State with legal descriptions of all parcels that may be conveyed. The Secretary will transfer archeological collections to the South Dakota State Historical Society. $750,000 is authorized for implementing this Act. Authorization of $750,000 for implementing the Act and reimbursing expenses incurred by the Secretary, Commission, and State Department of Game, Fish, and Parks.
